title: RS22581
content: The Securities Act of 1933 requires securities to be registered with the SEC before being offered to the public. The registration statement includes a prospectus for purchasers and Part II for inspection. Detailed information such as underwriters, business type, shareholders, debt, and assets must be disclosed. Regulations and specific requirements for the prospectus are outlined in the Act. The Securities Act of 1933 requires registration of securities with the SEC, including detailed information on business type, shareholders, debt, and assets in the prospectus. Section 10(a) specifies required information, with exemptions for certain transactions and securities. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 focuses on ongoing disclosure through periodic reports for issuers with securities traded on exchanges or specific asset and shareholder thresholds. Any issuer with securities traded on a national exchange or assets over $10,000,000 and 2,000 shareholders must register under the 1934 Act with the SEC. Registered companies must file detailed periodic reports with the SEC, including annual and quarterly reports with all material information for investors. Proxy solicitation information is also required. Failure to disclose material information is actionable under Section 18(a) of the Securities Exchange Act. The Securities Exchange Act requires companies with securities traded on a national exchange or assets over $10,000,000 and 2,000 shareholders to register with the SEC. Detailed periodic reports, including annual and quarterly reports, must be filed with all material information for investors. Failure to disclose material information is actionable under Section 18(a) of the Act. Additionally, the Investment Company Act of 1940 aims to protect investors who use others to manage and diversify their investments by requiring investment companies to register with the SEC and file specified information. Compliance with the act is necessary for participation in certain securities activities. The Investment Company Act of 1940 requires non-exempt investment companies to register with the SEC and file specified information to participate in certain securities activities. The act also regulates affiliations and interests of directors, officers, and employees of investment companies. Additionally, the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 defines an investment adviser as any person who advises others on securities value or investing, requiring registration with the SEC to use interstate commerce. The Insider Trading Sanctions Act of 1984 increases sanctions against insider trading to deter violations. Insider trading involves trading securities with material nonpublic information. The SEC can bring civil penalties against those who engage in insider trading, with penalties up to three times the profit gained or loss avoided. The Insider Trading and Securities Fraud Enforcement Act of 1988 expanded civil penalties for insider trading, increased jail terms and fines for securities law violations, initiated a bounty program for informants, and required firms to prevent misuse of inside information. The Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 aimed to reduce frivolous shareholder lawsuits. The Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 was enacted to address frivolous shareholder lawsuits, limiting them in federal courts by appointing a lead plaintiff, guaranteeing full disclosure of settlement terms, providing a safe harbor for forward-looking statements, and auditor disclosure of corporate information. The Securities Litigation Uniform Standards Act of 1998 (SLUSA) was enacted to prevent plaintiffs from circumventing the requirements of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995 (PSLRA) by bringing securities fraud cases in state courts. SLUSA mandates that securities fraud cases can only be brought in federal courts under specific criteria. The Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 was enacted in response to corporate scandals like Enron and WorldCom. It establishes a Public Company Accounting Oversight Board, restricts accounting firms from providing certain services to companies they audit, and requires additional disclosures for public companies and their officers. The act also addresses securities fraud and internal management controls. The Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 established a Public Company Accounting Oversight Board and restricts accounting firms from providing certain services to companies they audit. It also requires additional disclosures for public companies and their officers. Dodd-Frank, passed in response to the financial downturn in the early 21st century, made significant changes to financial regulation, affecting the securities industry in various ways. Title VII of Dodd-Frank focuses on regulating the over-the-counter swaps markets and sets jurisdictional parameters for the Commodity Futures Trading Commission and the SEC. Title IX of Dodd-Frank introduces new powers for the SEC, including the creation of an Office of the Investor Advocate and a whistleblower program for securities fraud. It also expands investor protection by regulating credit rating agencies, requiring shareholder votes on executive compensation, setting rules for proxy solicitation, and establishing a Public Company Accounting Oversight Board. Additionally, Title XV mandates SEC rules on disclosing minerals from the Democratic Republic of the Congo benefiting publicly traded companies. The STOCK Act prohibits Members of Congress and employees from trading stocks based on inside information received through their positions. The JOBS Act aims to ease securities reporting requirements to encourage funding for small businesses and startups, with a focus on emerging growth companies and crowdfunding. The JOBS Act aims to facilitate funding for small businesses and startups by easing securities reporting requirements. Title I focuses on emerging growth companies, allowing them to phase in SEC regulations and submit draft registration statements confidentially. Title III exempts certain companies from registration requirements under the 1933 Securities Act if specific conditions are met, such as limits on the amount of securities sold and the use of funding portals for transactions.
